DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
FOMC

The FOMC raised the fed funds rate target by 25bps to 2.25% - 2.50% (vs. Prev. 2.00% - 2.25%), in line with the analyst median forecast. The central bank also narrowed the trajectory of rate hikes going forward, now envisaging two hikes in 2019, and one in 2020 (previously it had seen three hikes in 2019 and one in 2020). Crucially, the FOMC lowered its estimate of the neutral rate (to 2.8% from 3.0%). Additionally, the central bank softened its guidance on future rate hikes, saying that “some further gradual increases” to rates (versus the previous “further gradual increases”). In terms of risks to the outlook, the Fed continues to see these as “roughly balanced”

In his statement, Chair Powell said “cross-currents” have emerged, and the Fed has seen developments that signal softening ahead, though the developments have not fundamentally altered its outlook. Powell reiterated comments from October that policy is not on a pre-set course, and talked about the Fed’s data-dependency. Powell said the FOMC sees some moderation of growth in 2019; tightening financial conditions and slower growth led the Fed to mark down inflation projections. Powell suggested that inflation trends can allow the Fed with patience in normalising policy. On the neutral rate, he suggested we are now at the bottom-end of the estimate of the neutral rate, while stating that there is a high degree of uncertainty about the path of future hikes; Powell stated that policy does not need to be accommodate and it was appropriate to be neutral. He also said the Fed took tightening financial conditions into account. On independence, Powell said political concerns played no role in the FOMC’s deliberations, and nothing would deter the Fed from doing what it thinks it the right approach. Elsewhere, Fed Chair Powell said that balance sheet policy will remain on auto-pilot.

ASIA-PAC

PBoC said to keep targeted medium term lending facility (TMLF) to support small and private enterprises which will be valid for 3 years. (Newswires)

US and China have clashed at WTO meeting, accusing each other of undermining multilateral trading system, US trade ambassador said that China is seeking to steal technology in strategic industries 'this is not acceptable' ; according to speeches seen by journalists. (Newswires)

DATA

UK CPI YY Nov 2.3% vs. Exp. 2.3% (Prev. 2.4%) (Newswires)


EU

European Commission has decided not to open the EDP on Italy; according to Radiocor. (Newswires)

Italian Economy Minister Tria says budget deal should show markets once and for all that Italy has no intention of leaving the Euro. He also added that the lower deficit won't impact pensions overhaul, budget measures and citizen's income being implemented April 1st, 2019. (Newswires)

Italy Economy Minister Tria said public debt/GDP ratio will rise slightly in 2018. (Newswires)

Italy reportedly targets debt/gdp ratio of 130.7% in 2019, falling to 129.2% in 2020, ANSA reports. (ANSA)

EU's Dombrovskis said if should something go wrong EU can return to disciplinary action against Italy in January. (Newswires)

ECB's Nowotny (Hawk) stated that his preference would have been for the Bank to phase out purchases of corporate bonds instead of sovereigns. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Libyan PM has given orders to reopen El-Sharara’s 315K BPD oilfield, but production has not restarted yet; according to a field engineer. (Newswires)

Saudi Finance Minister said he is "comfortable" with oil prices up to now and "relatively comfortable" in a worst-case scenario. (Newswires)

Saudi Energy Minister said Saudi Arabia is to cut 400k BPD in January to 10.2mln BPD; he said he is certain the Kingdom will extend cuts in April. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US has imposed fresh Russia-related sanctions according to a Treasury statement. (Newswires)

US

Senior White House official declined to say for sure that US President Trump will sign the government spending bill if passed. (CNBC)

US President Trump's Advisor Conway said Trump may consider a stopgap spending bill to February. (Newswires)

US Senate Majority Leader McConnell said congress is to seek passage of a temporary funding bill until 8th February. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted about Mexico paying for the wall indirectly via US gains from USMCA deal. (Twitter)

DATA

Canadian CPI Inflation YY (Nov) 1.7% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 2.4%) (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

FedEx (FDX) and UPS (UPS) opened lower after FedEx reported below expected EPS figures and lowered its guidance. Micron (MU) nosedived on the open following a miss on revenue estimates and lowering guidance below consensus. Allergan (AGN) underperformed in early trade after it withdrew its texture based breast implants from European markets after evidence they may be linked to cancer. Under Armour (UAA) traded lower after a downgrade at Atlantic Equities. General Electric (GE) opened higher as it announced plans to spin off its health care unit in an IPO. Eli Lilly (LLY) outperformed on the open on the back of a dividend increase as well as raising guidance. General Mills (GIS) traded higher to start the day after it reported EPS above estimates and affirmed its guidance. Diamondback Energy (FANG) outperformed following it announcing its 2019 CAPEX plan and a rise in its quarterly dividend. Best Buy (BBY) benefitted from an upgrade at MoffettNathanson. Energy stocks rebounded today inline with the bounce back in crude prices. * SPX -1.50% at 2506, NDX 2.19% at 6635, DJI -1.49% at 23322

Heading into the FOMC Meeting T-notes traded cautiously in a 120-26 -121-02 range; on the rate decision itself there was a two-way action with treasuries initially reticent to move before rising to 121-03. However, over the course of press conference, we saw further upside as Fed Chair Powell presented a cautious tone highlighting uncertainty ahead amid easing growth momentum. * US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE  10+ TICKS HIGHER AT 121-05+.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 19th December 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • * SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, treasuries up, dollar up, crude up.
  • * REAR-VIEW: Fed 25bps hike as expected, cuts rate hike trajectory, softens rate guidance; US and China clash at WTO; EU not to open EDP on Italy; existing home sales strong; Canadian CPI soft.
  • * AHEAD: BoJ, BoE, Riksbank Rate Decisions, Australian Jobs Report, UK Retail Sales, US Initial Jobless Claims & Philly Fed Business Index, Japanese CPI.

*  FOMC ANNOUNCEMENT: The FOMC raised the fed funds rate target by 25bps, in line with the analyst median forecast. The central bank also narrowed the trajectory of rate hikes going forward, now envisaging two hikes in 2019, and one in 2020 (previously it had seen three hikes in 2019 and one in 2020). Crucially, the FOMC lowered its estimate of the neutral rate (to 2.8% from 3.0%). Additionally, the central bank softened its guidance on future rate hikes, saying that “some further gradual increases” to rates (versus the previous “further gradual increases”). In terms of risks to the outlook, the Fed continues to see these as “roughly balanced”.

* DECISION ANALYSIS: Markets initially reacted with caution, with ES (H19) falling from 2885 to 2860 (eventually finding a low of 2535 pre the Powell presser), and T-Notes (H19) initially fell to 120-22 from 120-26, before paring back and rising to 121-01 (sending 10-year yields to the lowest since May); EURUSD went from 1.1435 to around 1.14, USDJPY 112.20 to 112.40. Perhaps the reaction can be explained by the fact that the narrowing of the trajectory of normalisation are an acknowledgement of slowing growth momentum; additionally, with the Fed in data-dependency mode, it will examine data that is essentially backward-looking, which some suggest could lead to a slower reaction function if conditions were to deteriorate, potentially, opening the door to a policy error.

* CHAIR POWELL PRESS CONFERENCE: In his statement, Chair Powell said “cross-currents” have emerged, and the Fed has seen developments that signal softening ahead, though the developments have not fundamentally altered its outlook. Powell reiterated comments from October that policy is not on a pre-set course, and talked about the Fed’s data-dependency. Powell said the FOMC sees some moderation of growth in 2019; tightening financial conditions and slower growth led the Fed to mark down inflation projections. Powell suggested that inflation trends can allow the Fed with patience in normalising policy. On the neutral rate, he suggested we are now at the bottom-end of the estimate of the neutral rate, while stating that there is a high degree of uncertainty about the path of future hikes; Powell stated that policy does not need to be accommodate and it was appropriate to be neutral. He also said the Fed took tightening financial conditions into account. On independence, Powell said political concerns played no role in the FOMC’s deliberations, and nothing would deter the Fed from doing what it thinks it the right approach. On the balance sheet, Powell said that the policy remained to allow run-offs to occur on autopilot. 

* PRESS CONFERENCE ANALYSIS: Although Powell talked up the strength of the US economy, he struck a cautious tone; specifically, 2019 will see a slowdown of growth, and there was a high degree of uncertainty on the rate trajectory. Additionally, he does not believe policy needs to be accommodative, and said neutral policy was now appropriate, giving traders little reason to jump into risk. Through his press conference, ES futures continued to slide, printing a low of 2489.50, while the USD continued to appreciate (particularly against the CAD, and AUD, less so vs the EUR and JPY, perhaps since the Aussie was a cleaner trade, and additionally, commodities came under pressure after it was confirmed Libya’s Sharara oil field was top reopen). T-Notes printed highs of 121-13+.

* TRADE: US and China have clashed at WTO meeting, accusing each other of undermining multilateral trading system; an US trade ambassador argued that China is seeking to steal technology in strategic industries stating that 'this is not acceptable' while a China envoy noted that 'reckless actions' by the US are the cause of the current trading system crisis. Elsewhere, US President Trump tweeted about Mexico paying for the wall indirectly via US gains from USMCA deal.

*  ITALY: Radiocor reported that the European Commission has decided not to open the EDP on Italy after accepting the 2.04% deficit target. Nonetheless, EU's Dombrovskis warned that the 2019 budget still raises concerns and therefore, should something go wrong, the EU can return to disciplinary action against the country in January. In related comments, PM Conte announced that citizens wage and pension reform will launch as intended; he confirmed that 2019 GDP growth is seen at 1% and he lowered the 2020 and 2021 deficit targets to 1.8% and 1.5%, respectively.

* EXISTING HOME SALES rose 1.9% to 5.32mln from 5.22mln and came in above the 5.20mln expectations. Unlike housing starts and building permits on Tuesday, the gains were spread across both multi-family and single-family components. Analysts at Pantheon did not see a rebound coming so soon given recent poor weather conditions as well as the significant impact of wildfires in California. They also warn that the danger may not be over since there is a lag in the data. Looking ahead, Pantheon analysts don’t think “the revival to last beyond the spring,” because they first anticipate mortgage rates to rebound.

* CANADIAN CPI softened in November and fell by 0.2% MM, pushing down the YY headline to 1.7% from 2.4%, slightly below the 1.8% consensus. Core measures posted at 1.9% YY not too far from the BoC inflation target of 2%; Scotiabank notes that “maintaining it there provides additional breathing room for a near-term forecast pause over the coming pair of meetings”. Looking at the components, the weakness in the data reflects the recent slump in oil prices while the strongest increase was seen in food.

* WTI (F9) SETTLES USD 0.96 HIGHER AT USD 47.20/BBL, BRENT (F9) SETTLES USD 0.98 HIGHER AT USD 57.24/BBL. Oil prices bounced back today after Monday's strong selloff after the DOE reported the third consecutive week of crude stocks draws. Macro sentiment improved on Wednesday as traders positioned for a dovish rate hike from the Federal Reserve, seeing WTI and Brent move higher together as US equity markets opened up into the green. However, some of the gains were pared back on the release of EIA inventories, which saw a draw of 497K barrels less than the expected draw of 2.4mln; some relief was seen in the products where distillates printed a draw of 4.2mln barrels, way below the expected build of 573K barrels. In other news-flow, the Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said Saudi would cut oil production in January by 400K BPD to 10.2mln BPD and adds he is certain cuts will be extended in April. Local reports from Libya said the 300K BPD capacity Sharara oilfield had reopened following an agreement met with protestors, although a protestor spokesperson later denied this, saying production would restart after their demands were met, as well as additional newswires reporting production was yet to resume.

SPX -1.50% at 2506, NDX 2.19% at 6635, DJI -1.49% at 23322. SECTORS: Energy -1.30%, Materials -1.42%, Industrials -1.84%, Cons Discretionary -2.23%, Cons Staples -0.87%, Healthcare -1.39%, Financials -1.32%, Tech -2.10%, Telecoms +0.31%, Utilities -0.02%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: FedEx (FDX) and UPS (UPS) opened lower after FedEx reported below expected EPS figures and lowered its guidance. Micron (MU) nosedived on the open following a miss on revenue estimates and lowering guidance below consensus. Allergan (AGN) underperformed in early trade after it withdrew its texture based breast implants from European markets after evidence they may be linked to cancer. Under Armour (UAA) traded lower after a downgrade at Atlantic Equities. General Electric (GE) opened higher as it announced plans to spin off its health care unit in an IPO. Eli Lilly (LLY) outperformed on the open on the back of a dividend increase as well as raising guidance. General Mills (GIS) traded higher to start the day after it reported EPS above estimates and affirmed its guidance. Diamondback Energy (FANG) outperformed following it announcing its 2019 CAPEX plan and a rise in its quarterly dividend. Best Buy (BBY) benefitted from an upgrade at MoffettNathanson. Energy stocks rebounded today inline with the bounce back in crude prices.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE  10+ TICKS HIGHER AT 121-05+. Heading into the FOMC Meeting T-notes traded cautiously in a 120-26 -121-02 range; on the rate decision itself there was a two-way action with treasuries initially reticent to move before rising to 121-03. However, over the course of press conference, we saw further upside as Fed Chair Powell presented a cautious tone highlighting uncertainty ahead amid easing growth momentum.

* USD: The Dollar reclaimed the 97.00 handle in the wake of the Fed hiking rates by 25bps, paring back some of the losses vs G10 rivals and EM currencies suffered earlier in the session.

* EUR: The single currency has extended gains vs the Dollar and across the board after confirmation that the EU has approved Italy’s revised 2019 budget with a 2.04% deficit target, albeit conditionally, narrowly and subject to period review. Eur/Usd sitting around 1.375 after a cautious Fed.

* NZD, JPY, CAD, GBP: The Kiwi slipped below 0.9800 in the aftermath of the Fed while NZ data in the form of Q3 GDP and November trade supported the pair earlier in the session. Meanwhile, Usd/Jpy pushed towards 112.50, the Loonie below 1.3500 and Pound below 1.2650, all victims of USD strength.

* AUD, CHF: Aussie close to 0.7100 in post-FOMC with losses exacerbated by the reopening of El Sharara oilfield (production has not restarted yet) while the Franc reclaimed 0.9900 and now towards 0.9950.

*  EM: Almost all benefiting to the detriment of the Usd, and especially recent laggards like the Try.

* COMING-UP:

* PREVIEW: BoJ policy announcement due Thursday 20th December 2018. The BoJ will conclude its last policy meeting of the year on Thursday and no major fireworks are anticipated given unanimous expectations for the Central Bank to maintain its policy settings of negative rates at -0.1% and the long-term yield target at around 0.0%. In addition, the BoJ is expected to keep its flexible approach on yields and reaffirm forward guidance maintaining current extremely low rates for an extended period. The Japanese Central Bank is also seen keeping its long-term JGB buying guidelines (holdings to increase at an annual pace of around JPY 80tln). Goldman Sachs expects the BoJ’s ETF and other purchase programmes to remain unchanged as well. Click here for the full RANsquawk preview.

* PREVIEW: Riksbank to publish rate decision on Thursday 20 December 2018 due at 08:30 GMT (02:30CST). The Rate decision is seen as “one of the most contentious in recent memory”. Particular focus will be set on commentary surrounding the poor Nov. growth and inflation figures. Click here for the full RANsquawk preview.

PREVIEW: Bank of England Monetary Policy Decision and Minutes Thursday 20th December 12:00GMT (07:00ET). MPC expected to vote 9-0 in favour of standing pat on rates at 0.75%. Brexit uncertainty likely to tie the hands of policymakers. Markets looking to see if political jitters will impact the MPC’s current rate outlook. Click here for the full RANsquawk preview.

subject: Fed raises FFR target range, as expected; cuts rate hike trajectory, softens rate guidance
content:
• Fed sees two rate hikes in 2019, one in 2020
  • Median view of appropriate FFR at end-2019 is 2.875% (prev. 3.125%), end-2020 is 3.125% (prev. 3.375%), end-2021 is 3.125 (prev. 3.375%), longer-run is 2.750% (prev. 3.000%)
  • Sees slightly lower economic growth and inflation in 2019 vs. September projections
  • Median Fed long run forecasts: GDP growth at 1.9% (prev. 1.8%), jobless rate at 4.4% (prev. 4.5%), PCE Price Index at 2.0% (prev. 2.0%)
  • Says economy, labour market remains strong but expects growth to slow to 2.3% in 2019 vs. 3.0% this year and inflation weaker at 1.9%
reaction_details: ES (H19) falling from 2885 to 2860 (eventually finding a low of 2535 pre the Powell presser), and T-Notes (H19) initially fell to 120-22 from 120-26, before paring back and rising to 121-01 (sending 10-year yields to the lowest since May); EURUSD went from 1.1435 to around 1.14, USDJPY 112.20 to 112.40.
analysis_details: The FOMC raised the fed funds rate target by 25bps, in line with the analyst median forecast. The central bank also narrowed the trajectory of rate hikes going forward, now envisaging two hikes in 2019, and one in 2020 (previously it had seen three hikes in 2019 and one in 2020). Crucially, the FOMC lowered its estimate of the neutral rate (to 2.8% from 3.0%). Additionally, the central bank softened its guidance on future rate hikes, saying that “some further gradual increases” to rates (versus the previous “further gradual increases”). In terms of risks to the outlook, the Fed continues to see these as “roughly balanced”.

Daily FX Wrap: Euro remains elevated, but Buck buckling into FOMC
content:
USD

The Dollar is wobbling again as the clock ticks down to the Fed and the index is flirting with Fib support just under 96.700 amidst widespread Greenback losses vs G10 rivals and EM currencies. The catalyst is quite simply heightened expectation that the final Fed policy meeting of the year will be more dovish or cautious in word after a 4th hike is delivered. This could be conveyed via the accompanying statement, dot plots and/or press conference from Chair Powell, with several looking to see whether the phrase about more gradual tightening being warranted is retained. Back to the DXY, some respite may be in the offing after another housing data beat (existing on top of starts and permits yesterday)  and assuming no further technical breakdown through 96.500.

EUR

The single currency has extended gains vs the Dollar and across the board after confirmation that the EU has approved Italy’s revised 2019 budget with a 2.04% deficit target, albeit conditionally, narrowly and subject to period review. Eur/Usd appears to have overcome some psychological hurdles if not quite chart resistance to trip stops around 1.1425 and is now eyeing previous December highs and a Fib ahead of 1.1450.

NZD/JPY/CAD/GBP

The next best majors in Dollar terms, as the Kiwi maintains 0.6850+ status before the FOMC and NZ data in the form of Q3 GDP and November trade. Meanwhile, Usd/Jpy has slipped to fresh multi-week lows, but not quite far enough to seriously threaten 112.00-05 expiry options (1+ bn). The Loonie and Pound shrugged off or completely ignored benign, but largely as forecast Canadian and UK inflation reports to outperform the Usd, with the former rebounding further from near 1.3500 lows and latter keeping above 1.2650 through more divisive Brexit debate at PMQs. Note, the Cad also derived a degree of support from a rebound in oil prices, albeit partly due to the soggy Buck.

AUD/CHF  

Marginal or relative underperformers as the Aussie unit hit a brick wall around 0.7200 yet again and was undermined by more US-China wrangling at the WTO, while the Franc hovered just below 0.9900 and lost ground against the aforementioned bullish Eur.

EM   

Almost all benefiting to the detriment of the Usd, and especially recent laggards like the Try.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 19th December 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Dollar continues to underperform major counterpart ahead of todays FOMC decision
  • US-China tensions have reportedly resurfaced at the WTO meeting
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian CPI, US Existing Home Sales, DoEs, FOMC rate decision and press conference

19th December 2018

Dollar continues to underperform major counterpart ahead of todays FOMC decision

US-China tensions have reportedly resurfaced at the WTO meeting

Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian CPI, US Existing Home Sales, DoEs, FOMC rate decision and press conference

ASIA

Asian equities were mostly lower amid cautious trade ahead of the FOMC rate decision, and after the attempted rebound on Wall St. where the S&P closed little above its 2018 low, while the Dow Jones was supported by gains in Goldman Sachs. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was pressured by oil names following the mass decline in the complex, while Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) initially traded with no firm direction amid a choppy JPY before digging deeper into losses and giving up the 21,000 handle. Sentiment across the region was also reflected by the 10% plunge in Softbank’s mobile business in its USD 24bln market debut. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were mixed as the former was supported by financial names with the four large banks in positive territory. Meanwhile, Mainland gains in real estates and utilities were offset by the decline in the energy and healthcare sectors. Finally, JGB futures posted the biggest intraday gain since 2016 on growing concerns over the global economy health, while futures purchases were also exacerbated after BoJ kept 5-10yr purchases steady at JPY 430bln.

China Commerce Ministry says China and US discussed trade and the economy on a Vice Minister level on Dec 19th. (Newswires)

China purchased an unspecified amount of US soybeans; according to traders. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8869 (Prev. 6.8854) (Newswires)
PBoC injected CNY 40bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 20bln via 14-day reverse repos; Net CNY 60bln.

Japanese Trade Balance Total Yen Nov -737.3B vs. Exp. -600.3B (Prev. -449.3B, Rev. -450.1B) (Newswires)
Japanese Imports YY Nov 12.5% vs. Exp. 11.5% (Prev. 19.9%)
Japanese Exports YY Nov 0.1% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 8.2%)

TRADE

US and China have clashed at WTO meeting, accusing each other of undermining multilateral trading system, US trade ambassador saying that China is seeking to steal technology in strategic industries 'this is not acceptable'; according to speeches seen by journalists. China envoy says that 'reckless actions' by the US are the cause of the current trading system crisis. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK’s SNP, Liberal Democrats, Plaid Cymru and Greens have tabled a vote of no-confidence in the government. SNP’s Blackford is hopeful that they will be granted time by the government to debate the matter before the Christmas recess. (The Independent)

Business Insider's Political Reporter Payne tweeted "Labour source says the party's position is unchanged. It'll table its own confidence motion after the meaningful vote when the moment is right." (Twitter)

Sky's Beth Rigby tweets "Cabinet source also told me y’day on the matter of immigration & Brexit, May will not pivot to Norway-style deal because she is adamant that Brexit must mean ending of FoM". (Twitter)

UK CPI YY Nov 2.3% vs. Exp. 2.3% (Prev. 2.4%)

UK Core CPI YY Nov 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.9%)

UK Core CPI MM Nov 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.1%

Belgium PM Charles Michel has resigned after no confidence vote. (Newswires)

EU's Dombrovskis says the commission has reached a deal with the EU over the budget, allows the avoidance of EDP. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump is said to have given the executive order for a Federal government shutdown on December 24th. (Washington Post)

GEOPOLITICAL

US Special Envoy for North Korea will visit South Korea this week to coordinated efforts to push North Korea to denuclearise. (Yonhap)

Canada's National Post reports that a third Canadian has been detained in China; Chinese Foreign Affairs Ministry state they are not aware of this. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are in the green [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.4%], with some outperformance seen in the FTSE MIB (+1.6%) with banking names such as UBI Banca (+4.0%) and Intesa Sanpaolo (+3.7%) benefitting from reports that the EU commission has accepted Italy’s 2019 budget deficit at 2.04%. Sectors are mixed with some outperformance seen in the telecom and consumer discretionary sector.

Other notable movers include GlaxoSmithKline (+6.6%) in the green as they are to create a new healthcare joint venture with Pfizer estimated combined sales of GBP 9.bln. With Fresenius SE (+3.0%) following an upgraded to buy at Goldman Sachs. Whilst Natixis (-6.5%) are at the bottom of the Stoxx 600 after reporting Q4 revenue will be 10% lower than the previous year. Whilst postal names such as Royal Mail (-2.6%) and Deutsche Post (-4.5%)  are down after FedEx cut their guidance.

FX

DXY - The Dollar remains depressed in the run-up to the FOMC in anticipation of a dovish hike if not quite one more and done as a growing number of pundits look for the accompanying statement and guidance to be tweaked via the dot plots and/or removal of further gradual tightening. The index has duly retreated from another 97.000+ test and is holding just above recent lows ahead of 96.500, with the December base so far around 96.360 and ytd peak circa 97.710-715 the obvious bearish and bullish targets depending on the tone of the Fed.

EUR/AUD/NZD - All vying for top G10 spot and biggest gainer vs the flagging Greenback, but with the single getting an extra lift or rather relief bid on the back of Italy and EU agreement on the 2019 budget that is likely to be officially announced by Italian PM Conte shortly. Eur/Usd has subsequently revisited 1.1400+ terrain, albeit just, while Aud/Usd has had another go at 0.7200 and the Kiwi is pivoting 0.6850 even though NZ current account data for Q3 was somewhat disappointing overnight. Note, decent option expiry interest may act as a drag on Eur/Usd with 1 bn at 1.1375 and the same amount between 1.1355-60 rolling off, while there is strong chart resistance ahead of 1.1450 at 1.1442 (earlier December peak) and 1.1445 (Fib).

JPY/GBP - Also firmer vs the Usd, with the former just off a marginal new mtd high, but perhaps restricted to an extent by option related flow as 1.2 bn resides between 112.00-05 and 1.5 bn sits from 112.40-50, while for the Yen there is also the BoJ’s final policy meeting of 2018 to consider just after tonight’s FOMC. Meanwhile, Brexit continues to put a brake on the Pound, or at least temper Sterling gains as Cable crests 1.2650 and Eur/Gbp hovers around 0.9000 with little reaction to broadly in line UK inflation data or a modest beat on CBI trends that seems to have been released early.

CAD/CHF - The marginal underperformers, with the Loonie still blighted by crude’s slump and diplomatic strains with China, but just off new ytd lows a fraction above 1.3500 ahead of Canadian CPI data, while the Franc meanders between 0.9910-35 and around 1.1300 vs the Eur.

SEK - The Swedish Krona is on the back foot below 10.3000 vs the Eur after more soft Swedish macro releases in the form of industrial and consumer sentiment that will put another dent in the case for hawks at Thursday’s Riksbank policy meeting.

FIXED INCOME

It’s a bit premature given several potential market movers from now until the Fed, but debt futures may have already marked out ranges with Bunds still lagging on the squeeze in BTPs, though off worst levels having slipped to a marginal new 163.24 Eurex low (-10 ticks vs +27 ticks at one stage). Meanwhile, Gilts and US Treasuries are ramped and camped, albeit down from their highs awaiting the final throw of the dice from the US Central Bank for 2018, and assuming some level of toning down or dialling back on policy normalisation beyond the widely anticipated ¼ point hike that has been flagged in this year’s 4 dot plots and not taken off the table.

COMMODITIES 

Brent (+0.1%) and WTI (+0.1%) remain in close proximity to recent lows, as global equity markets have begun stabilising, following on from yesterdays significant losses where WTI dropped by 7.3%. Prices were mostly unreactive to the surprise 3.5mln barrel build in API crude inventories, where consensus has been for a draw of over 2mln barrels. Markets will be looking to see if EIA data later in the session confirms this build or if the crude stocks consensus of -2.475mln barrels is correct; if the build is confirmed it will be the first in 3 weeks and may generate new downward price pressure.

Gold is trading relatively flat after reaching a 5-month high of USD 1251.43/oz earlier in the session, with the yellow metal continuing to benefit from a softer dollar ahead of the FOMC decision. Elsewhere, profit margins at Chinese steel mills has significantly narrowed in November as the Chinese government has removed overall winter production restriction, now allowing cities and provinces to decide output curbs based on their emissions levels.

Saudi Finance Minister says the 2019 budget allocation to the energy industry, mining and logistics is over 3 times higher than in the previous budget. (Newswires)

UK debt and STIR futures on a firmer footing ahead of CPI
content: In contrast to retreating Bunds and irrespective of relatively flat US Treasuries ahead of the Fed, Gilts have returned to Liffe in fairly buoyant mood alongside the Short Sterling strip. Today’s UK inflation data is expected to be softer overall and one of the shadow BoE MPCs is predicting an unchanged announcement from the real policy setters on Thursday in line with the overwhelming consensus, but the bid in domestic bonds and 3 month contracts appears partly corrective and Brexit-related as both sides gear up for the no deal scenario. Looking at early price action in more detail, Gilts have gradually climbed and recovered from a marginally softer open at 123.07 to 123.37 vs their previous 123.09 settlement and Short Sterling futures are 2.5 ticks ahead at best in the lead up to CPI before the CBI (also seen weaker) and then the FOMC.

subject: Bunds: fading after falling just shy of contract high, and while BTPs fly
content: A somewhat livelier than normal pre-FOMC start for the 10 year German benchmark that was marked up to 163.48 from Tuesday’s 163.34 Eurex close initially, and then got to within 3 ticks of the 163.64 contract high on follow-through buying before topping out, with additional downside pressure coming when BTPs returned to the fray. Bunds are now just off a 163.25 low as Italian bonds spike more than 2 full points at best on reports that Rome and Brussels have finally settled 2019 deficit differences. In fact, the 10 year Italian debt future has blasted through its previous December 13 contract peak and broken above the next technical resistance levels to briefly eclipse the 127.44 continuation high before running out of steam. Ahead, a speech from ECB’s Hansson and Italian PM Conte is scheduled to talk at 11.00GMT, but then the focus will turn to the Fed.

content:

If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.

  • Asian equities were mostly lower amid cautious trade ahead of the FOMC rate decision, and after the attempted rebound on Wall St
  • UK’s SNP, Liberal Democrats, Plaid Cymru and Greens have tabled a vote of no-confidence in the government
  • Italy's Government source said the EU Commission has accepted the 2019 budget deficit of 2.04%
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK and Canadian CPI, US Existing Home Sales, DoEs, FOMC rate decision and press conference

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities were mostly lower amid cautious trade ahead of the FOMC rate decision, and after the attempted rebound on Wall St. where the S&P closed little above its 2018 low, while the Dow Jones was supported by gains in Goldman Sachs. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was pressured by oil names following the mass decline in the complex, while Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) initially traded with no firm direction amid a choppy JPY before digging deeper into losses and giving up the 21,000 handle. Sentiment across the region was also reflected by the 10% plunge in Softbank’s mobile business in its USD 24bln market debut. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were mixed as the former was supported by financial names with the four large banks in positive territory. Meanwhile, Mainland gains in real estates and utilities were offset by the decline in the energy and healthcare sectors. Finally, JGB futures posted the biggest intraday gain since 2016 on growing concerns over the global economy health, while futures purchases were also exacerbated after BoJ kept 5-10yr purchases steady at JPY 430bln.

China Commerce Ministry says China and US discussed trade and the economy on a Vice Minister level on Dec 19th. (Newswires)

China purchased an unspecified amount of US soybeans; according to traders. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8869 (Prev. 6.8854) (Newswires)
PBoC injected CNY 40bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 20bln via 14-day reverse repos; Net CNY 60bln.

Japanese Trade Balance Total Yen Nov -737.3B vs. Exp. -600.3B (Prev. -449.3B, Rev. -450.1B) (Newswires)
Japanese Imports YY Nov 12.5% vs. Exp. 11.5% (Prev. 19.9%)
Japanese Exports YY Nov 0.1% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 8.2%)


UK/EU

UK’s SNP, Liberal Democrats, Plaid Cymru and Greens have tabled a vote of no-confidence in the government. SNP’s Blackford is hopeful that they will be granted time by the government to debate the matter before the Christmas recess. (The Independent)

Business Insider's Political Reporter Payne tweeted "Labour source says the party's position is unchanged. It'll table its own confidence motion after the meaningful vote when the moment is right." (Twitter)

Former Brexit Secretary Raab has urged PM May to give businesses a tax break to help weather a no-deal Brexit, funded using the GBP 39bln the UK would save after no longer needing to pay the EU. (Telegraph)

The Times Shadow Monetary Policy Committee believes that households should be spared an interest rate rise until the current political uncertainty clears early next year, assuming it does. (Times)

Italy's Government source said the EU Commission has accepted the 2019 budget deficit of 2.04%. (Newswires) This comes after sources from PM Conte’s office said Italy has received only verbal assurances from the EU Commission over the budget deal and it is reasonable to expect a positive outcome at EU commission meeting on Wednesday. Later, Italian Economy Minister Tria's spokesperson said Italy has completed a deal with the EU commission over the budget. (Newswires)

Belgium PM Charles Michel has resigned after no confidence vote. (Newswires)

FX


FX markets were choppy in which the DXY remained sub-97.000 and retreated to lows of 96.830 in the run-up to the FOMC interest rate decision, which is widely expected to result in a dovish hike. As such, EUR/USD was pushed further above of 1.1350 while GBP/USD breached 1.2650 to the upside. Meanwhile, USD/JPY swung within a 40-pip range after printing fresh Dec lows at 112.19 amidst the undecisive risk tone, with traders also citing the downside to bearish technical indicators. Elsewhere, antipodeans were also bolstered by the softer greenback alongside firmer base metal prices, with AUD/USD re-testing resistance 0.7200 ahead of its 100DMA at 0.7219 and NZD/USD shrugged off downbeat current account data to march further north of 0.6850. Finally, the Loonie was subdued and failed to benefit from the weaker buck as the decline in crude prices kept USD/CAD little changed around 1.3450.
 

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent traded sides-ways after the complex suffered its largest decline in over three weeks amid concerns of slower global growth and surging supplies from US and Russia. Prices were little changed after the release of the API crude inventories which showed a surprise build of almost 3.5mln barrels, focus is on the weekly DoE release where US production numbers will be closely watched as output surpassed 11mln BPD for almost two months. Elsewhere, gold mirrored the greenback and crawled higher ahead of the FOMC decision later today, while copper outperformed as prices consolidated after declining almost 3% yesterday.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (14 Dec) +3.452mln vs. Exp. -2.4mln (Prev. -10.18mln) (Newswires)

US said it is monitoring the El-Sharara oil field situation after Libya’s NOC declared force majeure at the 315K BPD oil field. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US Special Envoy for North Korea will visit South Korea this week to coordinated efforts to push North Korea to denuclearise. (Yonhap)

US

Treasuries drifted higher on Tuesday on the back of a volatile session for the equity market and as investors remained cautious ahead of tomorrow’s FOMC meeting. The curve saw some modest bull-steepening as most of the action was concentrated in the front end of the curve where yields were lower by c.5bps at settlement; longer date yields were lower by c.4bps. Spreads widened by less than 1bps with the exception of 10s30s which were slightly narrower. US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE 7+ TICKS HIGHER AT 120-30+

US President Trump is said to have given the executive order for a Federal government shutdown on December 24th. (Washington Post)

US Press Secretary Sanders said the Fed is independent but US President trump has the right to state his opinion on its policy. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the yield curve is a poor economic indicator. (Newswires)
